Early Access Game

Get instant access and start playing; get involved with this game as it develops.

Note: This Early Access game is not complete and may or may not change further. If you are not excited to play this game in its current state, then you should wait to see if the game progresses further in development. Learn more

What the developers have to say:

Why Early Access?

“Hive Jump is an ambitious game from a small team. With the inclusion of features like Online Multiplayer, Procedural Levels, and Daily Challenges, we hope to grow a strong community of players during Early Access who will help us test for bugs, improve the balance of weapons and enemies, and help refine the game for an amazing launch of the full version later this year.”

Approximately how long will this game be in Early Access?

“Our goal is to respond to as much Early Access player feedback as possible while also finishing the remaining content for the full version of the game. We estimate that achieving this will take approximately three months, but could extend until the end of the year if necessary.”

How is the full version planned to differ from the Early Access version?

“At the time of Early Access launch, the game will be approximately 80% content complete. The remaining 20% of content includes:

· Hive Queen Boss Battles
· Planetary Strategy Campaign Mode
· Story Content and Lore Screen
· Jumper Shouts and VO
· Improved Player Statistics and Achievements
· Localization for EFIGS+R
· Re-configurable Controls

Beyond these planned features and improvements, we will also be addressing player feedback from our Early Access community. We look forward to hearing from you!”

What is the current state of the Early Access version?

“We’ve invested over two years and thousands of work hours into Hive Jump already. We believe the fundamental game loop of joining your friends, outfitting you jumpers with equipment in the loadout screen, jumping into and exploring a procedurally generated alien hive, defeating bosses, and getting your missing results is a solid loop.

Our hope is that Early Access players will try playing the game solo, or with any number of friends totaling up to a fire team of four, and unlocking their entire arsenal of bug-killing weapons and devices. We’re also providing a Daily and Weekly Challenge mode to keep players coming back to try out the new content and bug fixes as we work towards release. The game has a lot of moving pieces and we’re hoping you’ll try everything you can think of and help us find bugs, eliminate them, and make the game a better experience for all players!”

Will the game be priced differently during and after Early Access?

“No. We feel Hive Jump is already a worthwhile value and don’t expect to raise the price after release. As an Early Access player, you will have the advantage of seeing the game develop and evolve, and even if you aren’t sure the Early Access version is worth full price, we hope you’ll stick with us and provide feedback that makes the game better for the full release.

We’re gamers ourselves and support the Early Access community as well, having discovered many of our new favorite games in this way. We’ve enjoyed watching them develop over time as new features are added and we hope you will have the same experience with Hive Jump!”

How are you planning on involving the Community in your development process?

“Our fans are our lifeblood. We’re looking forward to jumping hives with all of you in Early Access, and receiving your valuable feedback in order to make the game even better.

We will be active on our Steam Community forums, responding to as much of your feedback as possible. We also post monthly development updates on Kickstarter campaign site and spread that throughout various social media networks like Facebook and Twitter. Follow us on those platforms for the latest details.

We’re looking forward to jumping with you soon! See you in the hives!”

About This Game

In the 24th century, humanity is at war with a hostile alien race. Outnumbered a million to one, mankind’s only hope of survival is the J.U.M.P. Corps. Its mission is to fight the alien menace hive by hive and planet by planet.

You and your friends assume the role of JUMPERS, and blast your way through procedurally generated alien hives in chaotic run-and-gun 2D platforming action. Up to 4 Players band together in Local or Online Co-op to kill aliens, avoid traps, collect treasures and discover lost relics. Defeat fierce alien bosses to complete your mission and save the galaxy.

Key Features


  • Action Platforming: Engage swarms of aliens in frenetic combat. Avoid traps, withstand ambushes, discover treasures, rescue survivors, and more.
  • Co-op Multiplayer: Play single player, or local 2-4 player co-op. (online play via Steam is coming soon)
  • Procedural Levels: Jump into procedurally generated alien hives. Level modifiers like dark levels keep you on your toes and offer new challenges to overcome.
  • Unique Permadeath: Keep the transponder backpack in one piece! It is your mobile respawn point and if it is destroyed your team has no more lives.
  • Challenging AI: Intelligent and fierce enemies will hunt you throughout the hive.
  • Sci-Fi Arsenal: Pulverize aliens with pulse rifles, flamethrowers, and a variety of unlockable and upgradable weapons that persist between missions.
  • Hand-Designed Challenges: Plunder challenge rooms and uncover lost relics to boost the power of your jumpers for that mission.
  • Dynamic Lighting: Experience pixel-perfect dynamic lighting using Sprite Lamp.
  • Daily/Weekly Challenges: Compete with friends and strangers to see who is the greatest jumper in the galaxy with Daily and Weekly Challenge missions with Leaderboards coming soon.
  • Strategic Campaigns: The results of your jumps directly impact the ongoing galactic war against the aliens. Manage your planetary campaign between jumps in a turn-based strategy mode. (feature not yet present in Early Access)
  • Gamepad Support: Play Hive Jump using your favorite console controller.

System Requirements

    Minimum:
    • OS: Windows Vista / 7
    • Processor: Intel Core™ Duo or faster
    • Memory: 2 GB RAM
    • Graphics: 512 MB
    • Storage: 1100 MB available space
    Recommended:
    • OS: Windows Vista / 7
    • Processor: Intel Core™ Duo or faster
    • Memory: 4 GB RAM
    • Graphics: 1GB
    • Network: Broadband Internet connection
    • Storage: 1100 MB available space
    • Additional Notes: Xbox 360 controller or other XInput-compatible controller

HIVE JUMP its logo and the characters are trademarks of Graphite Lab, LLC.

Early Access Review
Posted: July 21
Starship Troopers meets Rogue Legacy.

You pick your weapon, grenade type, and your perk. Make your way through the hive. 3 areas, then a boss.

Sounds like a simple premise, right? NAH MATE. You have a backpack. A single backpack, between you and your three friends (if you're playing with any, there's no online multiplayer as of yet), and it's your respawn point. You HAVE to keep it safe if you want to make it to the later levels. Once the backpack is gone, so are your respawns. Work together!

Controls are tight, the music is amazing, the details are gorgeous (I mean ♥♥♥♥, lighting? In a pixel game? That's cheeky. <3), and the challenge is just right. Things start off slow, but increase at enough of a pace where you don't feel under or overpowered. You always have a chance to make it, if you play your cards right.

If you're on the ropes, wait for multiplayer. Really though, I can't recommend this enough. It's so good.

Early Access Review

Because this is an Early Access game, this review is made of suggestions/wishes rather than a conclusion.
(日本語のレビューは下の方にあります。 Japanese review is written at the bottom.)

The most important thing is:
Online multiplayer is not available yet. As this is a 4 player casual co-op game, I felt I only enjoyed 30% of the game elements.

Pros:
■4 player casual co-op action. The game is simple and fun.
■Unique weapons & equipments which actually giving different roles to teammates. One gives you many grenades, and another heals your ally.
■Like rogue-likes, procedural generated levels. This makes you feel fresh and giving one-chance playing for hardcore gamers.
■Pre-made special challenging stages with rewards. During procedural generated levels, you find these challenging stages. No respawn and full of death traps, but the reward is waiting and no penalty even if you failed.
■The result menu shows your rank and score. Funny topic for casual players with friends, and goal for hardcore gamers.
■Good retro musics of NES days. The musics remind me of old NES Megaman series.
■Pixel arts are great too, especially at terrains and Boss monsters.
(Features not available yet)
■Competitive Daily/Weekly challenges between friends or world.
■Turn-based Strategic Campaigns sounds fun.

Cons:
■Many parts are not available yet. Especially unavailableness of online multiplayer is critical for a game like this.
■Currently only have 4 normal enemy types. Small bugs, 2 big bugs, flying bugs. This makes me feel bit repetitive.
■Not very optimized for mouse+keyboard. Mouse aim is enabled, but cursor won't stop at the edge of the window.
■Locked on 30 FPS and high resolution setting just expands the window. Probably the dev considered for multiplayer problem and console version, but this made my eyes tired on high resolution. 800x600 or 1024x768 were best for me.
■Many resolution are supported, but not suited. Because almost all of the letters are made by dots, lower resolutions like 800x600 make some scale downed letters hard to read. Also, changing resolution from different aspect rates make in-game window size different (e.g. Changing 720x480 to 800x600 looks different than 640x480 to 800x600).

Overall, I think this game would be great once online multiplayer is added.
Though, for now singleplayer experience is very limited and many things are not optimized for PC yet. So if you interested in to multiplayer I suggest to follow the game on Steam and wait for its news.

■マウス+キーボード操作に、完全には対応していません。　マウスカーソルがウィンドウの端から飛び出します。
■動作が30フレーム固定で、高解像度の場合でも単にゲーム画面を拡大するだけなので、目が疲れます。　恐らくマルチプレイヤーとWiiU版を考慮しての事なのでしょうが、自分にとっては800x600か1024x768ぐらいがベストでした。
■色々な画面サイズが有効ですが、遊びにくいサイズが結構あります。　小さな画面サイズではドットで書かれる文字が潰れて読みにくかったです。　また、縦横比の異なる画面サイズから変更すると、同じ画面サイズでもゲーム内の画面の大きさが異なることがありました（例：720x480から800x600に変更した場合と640x480から800x600に変更した場合）。

総合的には、マルチプレイヤーが導入されればかなり良いゲームになるのではないかな、と思いました。　ただ、現状はシングルプレイヤーのみかつ未実装の機能が沢山あるという状態であり、更にPCに向けて最適化されているとも言い難いです。
興味はあるけど悩むというぐらいでしたら、Steam上でフォローしてマルチプレイヤー実装まで待つのが良いと思います。

genkipro
( 4.7 hrs on record )
Early Access Review
Posted: July 20
NOTE: This game was given to me by the developer for review purposes. This did not influence my review in any way.

==========================================================
---------------------------------------OVERVIEW-------------------------------------
==========================================================
Note: Hive Jump is currently in Early Access. This review covers versions 0.036.1211 and 0.039.1461.

Hive Jump is a two-dimensional side-scrolling science-fiction platformer / shooter with a retro theme, complete with pixel graphics and chiptunes. It includes some rogue-like elements, such as procedural level generation and perma-death.

You play a member of the J.U.M.P. Corps, humanity's last chance against an aggressive alien race. Your mission is to infiltrate the alien hives and destroy them, one by one.

==========================================================
----------------------------------------QUALITY-------------------------------------
==========================================================
Graphics - Hive Jump incorporates 2D pixel graphics that are very reminiscent of an 80s game. They move well and presumably achieve the desired effect, but I do find the colours a bit garish in places, and the colour scheme makes a lot of enemy types look very similar.

Animations on the player characters are good, and the different skins and insignias available are a nice touch.

Graphics options are limited to resolution and screen mode, as well as toggle switches for lighting and particles.

Sound - Weapon sounds are good and solid, and other sound effects are acceptable. Music fits in well with the retro feel of the game. I found it a bit annoying to begin with, but it's grown on me. There are no voices.

Gameplay - Hive Jump is a side-scrolling platform game with a focus on action and shooting rather than puzzles. It's designed to be played in either single-player or cooperative multiplayer mode, the latter with up to four players at once.

At the beginning of each game, each player chooses a Hive Jumper to control, with appearance defined by skin, colour, and insignia: symbols that appear over the characters' heads to help differentiate them. The only other differences between players are the equipment choices, which come in the form of a weapon type, an explosive type, and a utility item.

The game proper involves relatively simple 2D platforming coupled with shooter action as your team of Jumpers attempts to eradicate all of the aliens in each procedurally generated hive level, moving to the next by reaching the cave opening somewhere in the hive. Most defeated enemies drop yellow 'goo', which acts as a currency of sorts, and can be used to purchase weapons, upgrades, grenades, and utilities, but only after a completed hive level.

Hives can include doors into special rooms, which involve passing a platforming or shooting challenge, and only give you one chance before kicking you out and back into the main hive. I've completed a few of these and been rewarded with 'relics': so far either cold or 'electric' resistance, or increased flight duration, none of which carried over after the end of the game.

Controls are via keyboard and mouse or controller and are easy enough to learn, but the game doesn't currently support control display or key/button remapping, so it will take you a few minutes using either to work them all out. Available actions are move left and right, jump (double jump and hold to use jetpack), shoot, throw grenade, use utility, and interact. I tried both an Xbox360 controller and keyboard and mouse, and found keyboard and mouse easier and more accurate in the end.

The rogue-like aspects of procedural generation and perma-death are relatively well integrated. The hive levels do look very similar and could use a few more base components and layouts to feed the level generator, but so far I haven't seen any unwinnable levels or became stuck anywhere. The perma-death is a unique implementation whereby player characters can die and are replaced by reinforcements with the same appearance and equipment layout, but the team has a tactical backpack that calls these reinforcements. If the backpack is dropped (such as when a character carrying it dies), it can be attacked by any aliens on screen, and cannot be healed using normal means. If the backpack is destroyed then death is permanent, and it's game over. But any upgrades or unlocks you purchased carry over to the next time you play, as does any goo that was collected in a completed hive level (goo collected on the level on which you die is lost).

The game also includes daily and weekly challenges that differ from the normal game mode and can only be attempted once in each time period, which are a nice idea to increase replayability beyond the standard game mode.

Hive Jump is in Early Access and has some issues, as one might expect. My observations and suggestions are below:

- There seems to be no way to play a multiplayer game ("Find match" is always greyed out)
- "Lore" on the main menu is also greyed out
- There's a game-breaking bug where control is lost when the controller batteries go flat, and cannot be regained
- There are only limited unlocks available: I already had only one weapon left to unlock and have upgraded two to full power after playing for just a couple of hours
- The game gives no feedback to the player how many levels there are; what is the end goal, or how far away it is; or any sort of idea of progression
- When using keyboard and mouse, the menus force the player to use the mouse to select things, and the keyboard to confirm them, which is annoying
- Grenades don't 'feel' like grenades; I think it's something to do with inertia or bouncing, or both.
- There's no visible jump jet fuel meter, but they do stop working sometimes, and I found a relic that 'increased flight time'. Can we have a meter for this, next to the weapon heat meter, perhaps?
- So far I've only seen a very limited number of enemy types, with a few variations, making every game feel the same as the last
- A minimap would be useful

==========================================================
-------------------------------------PROS & CONS------------------------------------
==========================================================
Pros:
+ A fun homage to retro action platforming
+ Good integration of rogue-like gameplay elements, with an interesting twist to perma-death
+ Good chiptune music, if you're into that sort of thing

Cons:
- Graphics can be a bit hard on the old eyes, and lots of things look a bit too similar
- Enemies sometimes move through the edges of platforms and can attack from within the terrain sometimes
- No control layout information or reconfiguration
- No feedback on game progress
- Somewhat limited enemy types and procedural generation 'components' lead to many hives looking a bit too similar
- There's no way to pause, even in single player

==========================================================
--------------------------------------CONCLUSION-----------------------------------
==========================================================
With loud chiptune music and glary graphics that all looked similar, Hive Jump annoyed me at first. But after a while it all just clicked and I started having a good time. I think it will be a hoot with a group of friends.

According to the Steam page for the game at the time I first looked yesterday, Hive Jump included 'rougelike' elements. I'm really glad the developers decided to change it to 'roguelike' elements, because they're a lot of fun.

7/10

■４人プレイのワイワイ遊べる協力ゲーです。　シンプルなアクションゲームなので、難しく考える必要が無いです
■武器や装備がプレイヤー毎に異なる役割を遊べるよう考えられています。　グレネード沢山もてる装備や、味方を回復する装備などなど
■マップは自動生成なので、毎回新鮮な気持ちで遊べます。
■自動生成マップの道中には、開発チームの手によって作られた高難易度のステージなんかも登場します。　即死トラップ大量のオワタ式鬼畜ステージですが、クリアするとアイテムも貰えるのでやり応えがあります。
■結果画面ではランクや統計が見れるので、フレンド同士でワイワイ話題にしたり最高ランクでドヤ顔スクリーンショット撮ったりもできます。
■ファミコン世代には心地よいレトロ音楽でした。　イメージとしてはロックマンとかに近い感じ。
■ドット絵も素晴らしく、特に地形描写やボスモンスターの動きなんかが愛を感じました。
(未実装要素に期待を込めて)
■フレンドや世界と結果を競えるデイリー・ウィークリーチャレンジも実装されるようです
■ターン制のキャンペーンモードはどんな感じになるのか面白そうです。

悪い点:
■アーリーアクセスのゲームなので、かなりの部分が未実装です。　特にオンライン未実装はこの手のゲームとしては痛い
■現在、ボスを除く普通の敵が４種類しかいません。　アクションゲームとして敵のパターンが少ないというのは少し残念。
■マウス+キーボード操作に、完全には対応していません。　マウスカーソルがウィンドウの端から飛び出します。
■動作が30フレーム固定で、高解像度の場合でも単にゲーム画面を拡大するだけなので、目が疲れます。　恐らくマルチプレイヤーとWiiU版を考慮しての事なのでしょうが、自分にとっては800x600か1024x768ぐらいがベストでした。
■色々な画面サイズが有効ですが、遊びにくいサイズが結構あります。　小さな画面サイズではドットで書かれる文字が潰れて読みにくかったです。　また、縦横比の異なる画面サイズから変更すると、同じ画面サイズでもゲーム内の画面の大きさが異なることがありました（例：720x480から800x600に変更した場合と640x480から800x600に変更した場合）。

総合的には、マルチプレイヤーが導入されればかなり良いゲームになるのではないかな、と思いました。　ただ、現状はシングルプレイヤーのみかつ未実装の機能が沢山あるという状態であり、更にPCに向けて最適化されているとも言い難いです。
興味はあるけど悩むというぐらいでしたら、Steam上でフォローしてマルチプレイヤー実装まで待つのが良いと思います。

Early Access Review
Posted: July 21
Starship Troopers meets Rogue Legacy.

You pick your weapon, grenade type, and your perk. Make your way through the hive. 3 areas, then a boss.

Sounds like a simple premise, right? NAH MATE. You have a backpack. A single backpack, between you and your three friends (if you're playing with any, there's no online multiplayer as of yet), and it's your respawn point. You HAVE to keep it safe if you want to make it to the later levels. Once the backpack is gone, so are your respawns. Work together!

Controls are tight, the music is amazing, the details are gorgeous (I mean ♥♥♥♥, lighting? In a pixel game? That's cheeky. <3), and the challenge is just right. Things start off slow, but increase at enough of a pace where you don't feel under or overpowered. You always have a chance to make it, if you play your cards right.

If you're on the ropes, wait for multiplayer. Really though, I can't recommend this enough. It's so good.

Early Access Review
Posted: July 20
NOTE: This game was given to me by the developer for review purposes. This did not influence my review in any way.

==========================================================
---------------------------------------OVERVIEW-------------------------------------
==========================================================
Note: Hive Jump is currently in Early Access. This review covers versions 0.036.1211 and 0.039.1461.

Hive Jump is a two-dimensional side-scrolling science-fiction platformer / shooter with a retro theme, complete with pixel graphics and chiptunes. It includes some rogue-like elements, such as procedural level generation and perma-death.

You play a member of the J.U.M.P. Corps, humanity's last chance against an aggressive alien race. Your mission is to infiltrate the alien hives and destroy them, one by one.

==========================================================
----------------------------------------QUALITY-------------------------------------
==========================================================
Graphics - Hive Jump incorporates 2D pixel graphics that are very reminiscent of an 80s game. They move well and presumably achieve the desired effect, but I do find the colours a bit garish in places, and the colour scheme makes a lot of enemy types look very similar.

Animations on the player characters are good, and the different skins and insignias available are a nice touch.

Graphics options are limited to resolution and screen mode, as well as toggle switches for lighting and particles.

Sound - Weapon sounds are good and solid, and other sound effects are acceptable. Music fits in well with the retro feel of the game. I found it a bit annoying to begin with, but it's grown on me. There are no voices.

Gameplay - Hive Jump is a side-scrolling platform game with a focus on action and shooting rather than puzzles. It's designed to be played in either single-player or cooperative multiplayer mode, the latter with up to four players at once.

At the beginning of each game, each player chooses a Hive Jumper to control, with appearance defined by skin, colour, and insignia: symbols that appear over the characters' heads to help differentiate them. The only other differences between players are the equipment choices, which come in the form of a weapon type, an explosive type, and a utility item.

The game proper involves relatively simple 2D platforming coupled with shooter action as your team of Jumpers attempts to eradicate all of the aliens in each procedurally generated hive level, moving to the next by reaching the cave opening somewhere in the hive. Most defeated enemies drop yellow 'goo', which acts as a currency of sorts, and can be used to purchase weapons, upgrades, grenades, and utilities, but only after a completed hive level.

Hives can include doors into special rooms, which involve passing a platforming or shooting challenge, and only give you one chance before kicking you out and back into the main hive. I've completed a few of these and been rewarded with 'relics': so far either cold or 'electric' resistance, or increased flight duration, none of which carried over after the end of the game.

Controls are via keyboard and mouse or controller and are easy enough to learn, but the game doesn't currently support control display or key/button remapping, so it will take you a few minutes using either to work them all out. Available actions are move left and right, jump (double jump and hold to use jetpack), shoot, throw grenade, use utility, and interact. I tried both an Xbox360 controller and keyboard and mouse, and found keyboard and mouse easier and more accurate in the end.

The rogue-like aspects of procedural generation and perma-death are relatively well integrated. The hive levels do look very similar and could use a few more base components and layouts to feed the level generator, but so far I haven't seen any unwinnable levels or became stuck anywhere. The perma-death is a unique implementation whereby player characters can die and are replaced by reinforcements with the same appearance and equipment layout, but the team has a tactical backpack that calls these reinforcements. If the backpack is dropped (such as when a character carrying it dies), it can be attacked by any aliens on screen, and cannot be healed using normal means. If the backpack is destroyed then death is permanent, and it's game over. But any upgrades or unlocks you purchased carry over to the next time you play, as does any goo that was collected in a completed hive level (goo collected on the level on which you die is lost).

The game also includes daily and weekly challenges that differ from the normal game mode and can only be attempted once in each time period, which are a nice idea to increase replayability beyond the standard game mode.

Hive Jump is in Early Access and has some issues, as one might expect. My observations and suggestions are below:

- There seems to be no way to play a multiplayer game ("Find match" is always greyed out)
- "Lore" on the main menu is also greyed out
- There's a game-breaking bug where control is lost when the controller batteries go flat, and cannot be regained
- There are only limited unlocks available: I already had only one weapon left to unlock and have upgraded two to full power after playing for just a couple of hours
- The game gives no feedback to the player how many levels there are; what is the end goal, or how far away it is; or any sort of idea of progression
- When using keyboard and mouse, the menus force the player to use the mouse to select things, and the keyboard to confirm them, which is annoying
- Grenades don't 'feel' like grenades; I think it's something to do with inertia or bouncing, or both.
- There's no visible jump jet fuel meter, but they do stop working sometimes, and I found a relic that 'increased flight time'. Can we have a meter for this, next to the weapon heat meter, perhaps?
- So far I've only seen a very limited number of enemy types, with a few variations, making every game feel the same as the last
- A minimap would be useful

==========================================================
-------------------------------------PROS & CONS------------------------------------
==========================================================
Pros:
+ A fun homage to retro action platforming
+ Good integration of rogue-like gameplay elements, with an interesting twist to perma-death
+ Good chiptune music, if you're into that sort of thing

Cons:
- Graphics can be a bit hard on the old eyes, and lots of things look a bit too similar
- Enemies sometimes move through the edges of platforms and can attack from within the terrain sometimes
- No control layout information or reconfiguration
- No feedback on game progress
- Somewhat limited enemy types and procedural generation 'components' lead to many hives looking a bit too similar
- There's no way to pause, even in single player

==========================================================
--------------------------------------CONCLUSION-----------------------------------
==========================================================
With loud chiptune music and glary graphics that all looked similar, Hive Jump annoyed me at first. But after a while it all just clicked and I started having a good time. I think it will be a hoot with a group of friends.

According to the Steam page for the game at the time I first looked yesterday, Hive Jump included 'rougelike' elements. I'm really glad the developers decided to change it to 'roguelike' elements, because they're a lot of fun.

7/10
